title: Gravitational Dual of Tachyon Condensation
summary:
We study a system of N D3-branes in which open string tachyons survive in the
low energy alpha' -> 0 limit. We compute the height of the tachyon potential
both in the weak and strong couplings by using N=4 super Yang-Mills and the
dual AdS_5 descriptions respectively. We find an exact agreement between the
two descriptions in the large N limit. This provides an example of
gravitational duals of open string tachyon condensation.

summary_detail.value:
We study a system of N D3-branes in which open string tachyons survive in the
low energy alpha' -> 0 limit. We compute the height of the tachyon potential
both in the weak and strong couplings by using N=4 super Yang-Mills and the
dual AdS_5 descriptions respectively. We find an exact agreement between the
two descriptions in the large N limit. This provides an example of
gravitational duals of open string tachyon condensation.

author: Shinji Hirano
arxiv_comment: 4 pages, v2: references and footnotes added
fulltext:
RIKEN-TH-156, DAMTP-2009-44

Gravitational Dual of Tachyon Condensation
Gary W. Gibbons∗
DAMTP, University of Cambridge, Wilberforce Rd, Cambridge CB30WA, U.K.

Koji Hashimoto†
Theoretical Physics Laboratory, Nishina Center, RIKEN, Saitama 351-0198, Japan

Shinji Hirano‡

arXiv:0906.0401v2 [hep-th] 23 Jun 2009

The Niels Bohr Institute, Blegdamsvej 17, DK-2100, Copenhagen, Denmark
We study a system of N D3-branes in which open string tachyons survive in the low energy α′ → 0
limit. We compute the height of the tachyon potential both in the weak and strong couplings by using
N = 4 super Yang-Mills and the dual AdS5 descriptions respectively. We find an exact agreement
between the two descriptions in the large N limit. This provides an example of gravitational duals
of open string tachyon condensation.

I.

INTRODUCTION

There has been considerable progress in understanding
non-perturbative aspects of string theory with or without supersymmetries. These developments culminated
in the gauge/string duality primarily in supersymmetric
cases [1]. Meanwhile, in non-supersymmetric cases one of
the most remarkable progress is the open string tachyon
condensation [2]. However, these two developments have
been rather orthogonal to each other, except for twodimensional string theories [3]. In this note we study an
open string tachyon condensation in the gauge/string duality and provide an example in which these two connect
at the quantitative level [14].
In formulating tachyon condensations in the
gauge/string duality, one immediate obstacle is that the
mass squared of open string tachyons is of order O(1/α′ )
which may not be visible in the field theory limit α′ → 0.
However, there exist systems in which the open string
tachyon mass remains of order O(1) (in an appropriate
unit) in the limit α′ → 0. One such example is a system
of intersecting branes at angles. The mass squared of
open string tachyons stretched between intersecting
branes is proportional to θ/α′ where θ is an angle. In
this case we can take the α′ → 0 limit, keeping θ/α′
fixed finite. This type of open string tachyons manifest
themselves as unstable modes in the gauge theory in the
low energy α′ → 0 limit of intersecting D-branes [5]. In
the present paper we consider a T-dual version of the
system studied in [5] in the 't Hooft limit, N → ∞ and
gY M → 0 with λ = gY2 M N fixed finite.
One of the most important aspects of open string
tachyon condensation is that unstable D-branes which
support open string tachyons disappear after the
tachyons are condensed. Accordingly, Sen's conjecture

states that the height of the tachyon potential equals the
tension (energy density) of unstable D-branes [2]. Hence
the height of the tachyon potential is one of the most important and unambiguous quantities in the open string
tachyon condensation. The main objective of this paper
is to compute the height of the tachyon potential both
in the gauge theory and the dual AdS gravity for a large
N D3-brane configuration and to see if they agree. We
indeed find an exact agreement in the large N limit, thus
providing a simple example of gravitational duals of open
string tachyon condensation.

II.

BRANE CONFIGURATION

We consider a brane configuration of a D3-D1 bound
state parallel to coincident N D3-branes at some distance. The low energy description of this system is given
by N = 4 U (N + 1) super Yang-Mills (SYM) theory.
A D1-brane on D3-branes is represented by a magnetic
flux. Our brane configuration is thus described by the
following gauge and adjoint scalar fields
F23 = diag(B, 0, 0, * * * ) ,
Φ = diag(φ, 0, 0, * * * ) ,

where the magnetic flux B is T-dual to the aforementioned angle θ, and B and φ are the constant parameters.
This is a classical solution of the SYM theory. It should
be clear that the D3-D1 bound state is separated from
the N D3-branes by the distance 2πα′ φ.
When √the D3-D1 bound state is close to the N D3branes ( α′ φ ≪ 1), there appear tachyonic fluctuation
modes in the off-diagonal entries of the gauge and scalar
fields. This is a manifestation of string excitations connecting the D3-D1 bound state and the N D3-branes [5]
(see also [6] for its relevance to D-brane reconnections).
More precisely, the lowest excitation of these strings has
the mass squared

Thus a tachyon develops for φ < B. We would like to
stress that this tachyon has survived in the field theory
limit α′ → 0. Hence it is visible in the gauge/string duality where the low energy α′ → 0 limit of N D3-branes
is dual to the string theory on AdS5 × S 5 . Note that
when B = 0, this configuration is a point in the Coulomb
branch of N = 4 SYM. When B 6= 0, the Coulomb
branch is lifted and the configuration is no longer supersymmetric.
III.

THE POTENTIAL HEIGHT AT WEAK
COUPLING – FIELD THEORY

We now compute the height of the tachyon potential
based on the Sen's conjecture. At weak coupling λ =
gY2 M N ≪ 1 we can use the classical YM theory to evaluate the potential height. The top of the tachyon potential corresponds to the φ → ∞ limit at which the D3-D1
bound state and the N D3-branes are infinitely separated
and do not feel an attractive force (in terms of N = 4
SYM theory, the one-loop potential vanishes for φ → ∞).
The total energy density is given by

When φ < B, the tachyon develops. The endpoint
of the tachyon condensation is a bound state of N + 1
D3-branes and D1-branes (this is a T-dual of D-brane
reconnections in [6]). Initially the D1-branes are bound
to a single D3-brane isolated from the N coincident D3branes. The D3-D1 bound state is attracted to the N D3branes (φ decreases) and they coalesce (φ = 0). In this
process the D1-branes distribute themselves uniformly
among N + 1 coincident D3-branes. The total D1-brane
charge trF23 is conserved in the process. Thus the D1brane charge per each D3-brane is B/(N + 1);

Note also that we could have computed the potential
height without introducing φ. However, the role of φ
is to dial the instability of our unstable brane system
and catalyse the process of tachyon condensation. In the
dual gravity description, as usual, the energy scale φ is
mapped to the radial distance.
IV.

THE POTENTIAL HEIGHT AT STRONG
COUPLING – GRAVITY DUAL

We next compute the potential height at strong coupling
λ = gY2 M N = 2πgs N ≫ 1. The low energy limit of N
D3-branes is dual to the string theory on AdS5 × S 5 . So
in the dual description at λ ≫ 1 we treat the D3-D1
bound state as a probe D3-brane with a magnetic flux
put in the AdS5 × S 5 geometry.
The low energy effective action of a probe D3-brane in
the AdS5 ×S5 geometry is given by the Dirac-Born-Infeld
action plus the Chern-Simons term (Ramond-Ramond 4form coupling) with the ansatz, r = r(t, x). The AdS5
metric is
ds2 =

This is the height of the tachyon potential at weak coupling. Note that since the effective coupling constant of

We thus find an exact agreement with the weak coupling
field theory result (7) in the large N limit. Note, however,
that the value of the potential at the bottom differs –
B 2 /2λ in the field theory and zero in the gravity.
As we have just seen, the AdS description of the (lifted)
Coulomb branch of N = 4 SYM encodes the height of the
tachyon potential. However, the open string tachyon is
only a valid picture in the weak coupling field theory, as
it appears as a small fluctuation mode of the gauge and
scalar fields. So in the strong coupling one cannot directly observe the open string tachyon. In other words,
the gauge/gravity duality is an open string (loops)/closed
string (tree) channel duality. Hence in the gravity description the open string tachyon is integrated out and
cannot be directly observed [15]. However, there is no
contradiction in the agreement we found. The height of
the tachyon potential is the energy of an unstable brane
and conserved at any gauge couplings. So the potential
height is an observable in the gravity description.
It is, however, noteworthy that the value of the potential height in the large N limit is not renormalized,
remaining the same value from weak to strong coupling
[16]. This calls for an explanation. The reason may
be that the magnetic flux B on the D3-brane is small
B ≪ 1/α′ in the D-brane set-up prior to the decoupling
(field theory) limit. Hence our system of a D3-D1 bound
state parallel to N D3-branes at some distance is close to
a supersymmetric configuration. It is often the case that
not only BPS states but also near-BPS states are protected against stringy α′ corrections [10]. In the decou√
pling limit the effective α′ef f of the AdS string is 1/ λ.
We thus believe that this is the reason why we find an exact agreement between the gauge theory and the gravity
results in the large N limit.
V.

SUMMARY AND DISCUSSIONS

In this note we provide an example of open string tachyon
condensations in the gauge/string duality. The idea is
to consider a brane configuration in which open string
tachyons survive in the field theory α′ → 0 limit. One
can explore various similar brane set-ups by generalising
the example we presented. However, we find it more
illuminating only to discuss a single simple example.
We would like to give a brief discussion on topological
defects in the tachyon condensation and make a comparison between our study and the geometric tachyon
observed by Kutasov [11].

[1] J. M. Maldacena, "The large N limit of superconformal
field theories and supergravity," Adv. Theor. Math. Phys.

First we discuss topological defects in the tachyon condensation [2]. In the present set-up the topological defect
is a D(-1)-brane. The reason is as follows: Our brane
configuration consists of a D3-D1 bound state and N
D3-branes. The tachyonic modes come from 1-3 and 3-1
strings stretched between the D1-brane dissolved in the
D3-D1 bound state and the N D3-branes. So the tachyon
in question is a complex tachyon. When the complex
tachyon condenses, the topological defect is co-dimension
2 relative to the parent unstable brane. In N = 4 SYM
the tachyonic modes about the background (1) are the
ground state of the Landau level and localized in the
(x2 , x3 )-plane orthogonal to the magnetic flux B. Hence,
the parent unstable brane is effectively a D1-brane extended along the (x0 , x1 )-directions. We thus expect a
D(-1)-brane descended from the tachyon condensation as
a vortex on the D1-brane. In the weak coupling it is possible to analyse the vortex solution. However, it seems
rather difficult to study the nucleation of this topological defect in the gravity dual, since we cannot directly
see the tachyon. In general it would be challenging but
very interesting to study the nucleation of topological defects in the gravity dual and compare them with the field
theory counterparts.
Finally we make a brief comment on the geometric
tachyon. Kutasov made an intriguing observation in [11]
that the Dp-brane effective action in the k = 2 NS5branes throat on a transverse circle coincides with the effective action of the non-BPS D(p+1)-brane [12] wrapped
on the circle in the zero radius limit. The transverse circle
scalar on the Dp-brane is identified with the tachyon on
the non-BPS D(p + 1)-brane. It was further argued that
the two descriptions become identical via a second order
phase transition [13]. In comparison, in our case the geometric (radion) instability in the AdS space is related
to the open string tachyon via the gauge/string duality.
However, it is not possible to map directly between a geometric (radion) mode on one side and a tachyonic mode
on the other, as discussed above. Hence the geometric
manifestation of tachyon condensation in our study is
rather different from the geometric tachyon and they are
not related to each other in any obvious ways.
